But dance all night long, on St. Patrick's day,
The bagpipes shall fiddle Graamudgey gramagh,
While we swill down Skolrankey an good usquebagh,
When I wawk in the strate, I'll be led by a trupe;
Coming after an crying,—"Long life to Trushoop!"

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: An excellent song 'pon my soul! well com∣pos'd and well sung!

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: And well tim'd too! he! he! he!—Is it one of your own composition, Mr. Trushoop?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Why you devil you!—do you tink now, an I'd sing any body's songs but my own!—by my sowl! now, an I'll chalenge the whole college of Dublin it's self, to fellow me the like of it!

SP.SPEAKER: Hum, Quad. and Parch.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: (Aside.) Hah! ha! ha!—a queer dog! an ec∣centric genius!—Well, gentlemen▪ at eleven o'clock we're to meet at the stone-bridge, near the mill;—it will not be prudent to go altogether, lest we be dis∣cover'd; whoever arrives there first, let him wait for the rest, and as they approach they must hail with the watch-word, canoe!—those within must answer with the same word; by observing this, we shall prevent mistakes and discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Aye!—aye! the utmost care and circumspec∣tion are necessary, we can't be too cautious; the ob∣ject we are pursuing is equal to one whole year's re∣venue of the United States!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Fath! and I'll hollow canew! an canew! all night long in the morning, if you plaze.

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Unless you're determined to follow implicitly my directions, when we come to action, 'twill be in vain to proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: I'll do nothing but what you order, Mr. Rat∣tletrap, indeed I won't! the spirits won't hurt us, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Don't be afraid—take no rash steps—follow my directions, and not a hair of your heads shall be injured! Now, gentlemen, 'tis time to close, 'tis need∣less to say any more, now the plan's settled. Remem∣ber eleven o'clock, at the stone-bridge, each of you repair home, and bring all your tools with you, we'll break up for the present, I'll away home, and put on my magic habit—otherwise, I shall have no power over the invisibles!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: I'll go and get de tools, and bring a little re∣freshment wid me.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Fath! an I'll fatch my gauging-rod, an all the tools in the shop, if you want um, becaze why—I'll have no 'casion to uze um after this, honey!

SP.SPEAKER: Buc.
SP.P: Ize feetch my Andra we me, an then Ize fece the deel hims! he appear.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: And I'll bring he instruments with me, they are all in excellent order, and well prepared.

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Now gentlemen, lt's go with good hearts, there's nothing like putting a good face on these mat∣ters. If you'll bear chorus, I'll sing you a song before we set off. Come, fill your glasses.

SP.SPEAKER: All, say,
SP.P: With all my hear! They fill their glasses▪

LG.L: The merchant roams from climes to climes,
Regadless of his pleasure,
To hardships and fatigue resigns,
When in pursuit of treasure.
Chorus—And a digging, &▪
See now the lucky hour it comes,
With pick-axe and with fade,
A little digging,—oh! my sons,
And then our fortune's made! Chorus.
Let's boldly venture on the ground!
And seize the glorious chest,
No joy on earth like gold is found,
To ease the human breast! Chorus.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. A Room in Trushoop's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Dolly!—Dolly!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Come hither, girl!—quick! quick!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Coming, Ma'am.— (Aside.) What the deuce i the matter now?—sure the house is on fire!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Trus.
SP.P: Why Doll Sword I say—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Here, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: How ong you stay, hussey?—a body must split their troats afore you cum—go your ways, an put on the tay-kittel, quick! make haste girl! do you hare?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes ma'am— (Aside.) —Is that all? Exit Dolly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: How she stands?—Gaping—I seem in a flutter—my heart fales as light as a fedder,—I don't know what ales me—poor Trushoop! an I wonder what he'll think, when I tell him all poor devi! an why didn't he tell me himself then? an I shou'dn't have scowlded him, an bate him, an starved him so; but sure, an its his own fault, but I'll soon make it up with him, Dolly! I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Does the kittle bile?—you're a plagey while about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Just now, ma'am. (Aside.) Plague on yourse'f! you're in a devil of a hurry, I think!—won't give one time to blow the fire, and just come from stuffing her∣self at Mrs. Trowell's, and not satisfied; I'll warrant her, she's drank twenty dishes of tea, and eat half a cord of toast and butter!—I hate such gormandizing devils!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: It seems ev'ry minnet was an hour with me, I fale vary comical—well, it will be over bye an bye, an fath! an I'll have a better carpet than Mrs. Trowell's, an all these ould fashion chairs, an tables, an luckin-glasses.—I'll pack to the vandue, an I'll buy good Moll-Hoggeny ones—plate, china, an ev'ry thing alse, shall be of the newest taste an highest cut, an why shou'dn't it? sure an I can afford it now? Augh! an good luck to 'um, I say.—Dolly, now an what are you about?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Blowing the sire, ma'am. (Aside.) What the devil do you think?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Why now! an how long will you blow it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: 'Till it boils, ma'am.— (Aside.) To be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Why don't you cum then you pokeing toad you!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Coming Ma'am. (aside.) I believe in my soul! she's got the influenza, or the ravenous fever, or some∣thing!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Well, an that self same Mrs. Trowell, is a Jewel of a woman,—what pashence she has; an I wish I had half so much; but fath! an I never will— An why don't you come, you stomakin, with the tay-kittel? bring it along, I say!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly,
SP.P: Yes, ma'am! I'm coming. (Aside) Curse the kettle, it will never boil, I can't make it boil for my soul! smoaking my eyes out, and be bother'd so, I swear! I'll plague myself no longer about it, she shall have it as it is, boil or not boil, the devil a bit I care!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Well cum away then, you pokeing toad you!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: (aside.) O! hold your jaw! you brimstone devil!—Coming ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: An did it bile now?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, over and over again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Curse you, an what made you so long then?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: To make it boil well, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am. (Aside.) Hitey titey, and what's all this going on? some fun, I believe in my soul! Hah! hah! hah!—Oh! goodee, goodee oh! we shall see presently. Exit DOLLY.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus
SP.P: Well indeed! an I believe it's true enuff, an I have dram't it, or read it in some ould alminac somewhere, that "there is great joy over one sinner that rapanteth." Troth! an I'm shure an I rapant of of starving him so, an poor Trushoop will have grate joy now, when he knows what I'm going about to do for him, poor sowl! an he must be vary hungry, so he must, not a drop has he ate in my houshe, this six days to cum, an indeed, an indeed, he is one of the best hus∣bands I ever see! Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. A Room in Moll Placket's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: What cheer, Moll? let's taste your head, (Kisses her.) How stands the wind? is the coast clear? no danger of the enemy?

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: No, no, he has no certain time of coming, except after church on Sundays; and then he never fails, if the old fellow succeeds in this night's enter∣prise, I'll make your fortune for you, my boy!

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: Why! what the devil has Raccoon spied now? is there a galloon in chase? or, is he going to turn pirate?

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: No, no, but he may thank the pirates for it!

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: How, how Moll? tell me, you little dear dog you, (Chucking her under the chin.)

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: I tell you indeed!—a body wou'd—well, can you keep a secret then?

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: Aye! can I, as snug as a Free-mason; If ever I blow you, blast me! you know me better: If one word goes through my head rails, the devil blow me to Halifax, or Botany-Bay.—Aye Moll! the next hur∣ricane blow me off the main-top-gallant-yard! three leagues astern, and be swallow'd up like Jonathan swallow'd the whale! That's enough! and now I'll kiss the book on it. (Kisses her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Well, come, I'll tel you—You must know, that Mr. Hum has got a letter, and a heap of papers, from his sister-in-law in England, giving an accon, where there's a vast deal of money, that was for∣merly buried by the pirates!

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: Money! buried by the pirates? the evil!— aye Moll, that's true! I've often heard that Black∣beard hid his money, somewhere by the river's side; but how the devil came she by the papers?

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Why you fool!—she's Captain Blackbeard's great-grand-daughter, and they were preserved in the family till they were sent to Mr. Hum, and you know Raccoon is a Free-mason too, so he is to assist him, and they are to go shares.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: But how do you know that Hum's a Free-mason?

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Why he told me so, and they always call one another brother, and they keep this business as secret as their masonry, but I wheedled Raccoon out of it, in spite of all his cunning.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: By heav'ns! I shou'dn't like him on board the Europa!—he'd make a damn'd fist in the Killecranky trade—he'd throw out a signal, and the custom-house officers wou'd soon bear down on us—away goes ship and cargo by the mast—by the Lord Harry, he'd soon make beggars of my owners—But tell us, Moll, how the devil did you pump it out of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: That's none of your business, sauce-box— women like me, have always a lure to catch the men's secrets!

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: True Moll—but we'll talk further on this sub∣ject another time, this sort of chit-chat keeps us at long shot, let's step into the state-room, you know the old saying, "Time and tide waits for no one."

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P:
Softly!—don't be too hasty, let's make the door fast first. (She locks the door.) Though I love your
little finger better than Raccoon's whole body; yet I must keep in with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: Aye! that's true Moll—I should be loth to quarrel with an owner, because he did not understand navigation!

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: You know he maintains me, (after some sort) finds me a house to live in, fathers all my children, and a husband can do no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: Right, Moll! now we're all snug, the hatches all secur'd. Sings.

LG.L: No girl with Placket can compare,
She is so charming, sweet, and fair!
Such rosy cheeks, and nut-brown hair!
There's none like Molly Placket.
When'ere from sea I do return,
I for my Placket singe and burn,
Good luck, Raccoon, 'tis now my turn,
Come, come my lovely Placket.

SP.P: Come Moll, now I'll try what the clues of your hammock are made of.

DIV3.STAGE: (As they walk towards the upper part of the stage, a scene opens, and discovers a bed, table, and two bottles on it, with a broken glass over one, and a candle stuck in the other.—A knocking at the door.)

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: Zounds! what's this? the devil has ow'd me a spite this long time, and now he has brought the ene∣my upon me, now I'm land lock'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Who's there?—who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: (Without.) It's only me, my liddle dear pet— open de door.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: (Aside.) Oh! curse his head!—Pet's a com∣ing! Pet's a coming, dear Cooney!

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: Where the devil shall I stow myself? by the Lord Harry!—there's no dropping astern here.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Creep under the bed, and your as safe as a thief in a synagogue!

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: Aye, Moll! down the fore-suttle, or, any port in a storm, damme!

DIV3.STAGE: Topinlift goes under the bed, and she opens the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: What brings my dear Cooney back so soon? no misfortune, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: No, no; no misfortune, only I left sum tings under de bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: (Aside.) Curse your contrivance, now I'm blown. What things, my dear Cooney, did you leave there? (Aside.) Oh! invention! thou darling genius of my sex, assist me, or I'm ruin'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Nutting, my dear pet, but de spade, de pick-axe, and de spit. But, what makes you look so sup∣pris'd! child?

SP.SPEAKER: Plac.
SP.P: Why, I was afraid you'd catch me, and indeed you had like to have done so, (affects a laugh.) He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Seech what? seech how? What de debil do you mean by seech? Dad! I begin to tink it isn't all lies dat I hear about you, Mrs. Placket, tell me this instant who you hab wid you, or I'll shake you like de debil! (He shakes her, and she bawls.) What ebil, you tink to impose upon me, wid you he! he! he! I'll know de trute afore I done, hussey!

SP.SPEAKER: Plac.
SP.P: Oh! my dear Cooney!—do let me go, and I'll tell you the truth—indeed I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: (Peeping.) Oh! the brimstone whore!—I wish I was on board the Europa!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Well, come den—confine youself to de true, hussey!

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: (Peeping.) By the Lord Harry! the storm ga∣thers, we shall have foul weather soon—I must bowse taught my rolling tackles!

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Lord Sir! I'm afraid to tell you—you look so angry—I'll tell you in the morning, when your passion's over.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: I'll know it instantly, you vile strumpet you— or I'll shake you to atoms. (Shakes her again, and she bawls.)

SP.SPEAKER: Top
SP.P: (Peping.) It comes thicker and faster,—here's a damn'd stink of bildge water along-side.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: I'll tell you all—if you'll let me go.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Tell den hussey! dis minnet!
(Peeping.) Ava! there—belay that, I must out tomkins, and prepare for a broadside—damme.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Look at this book. (Gives him a Dutch almanac.)

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: (Peeping.) No nea! steady there!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: What of dat?—why it's High Dutch.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Can't you read it?

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: No—not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack
SP.P: (Aside.) I'm glad of it!—Why then, you must know▪ when I was about fifteen years of age, I lived at Germantown with my uncle, a high German Doctor, who could tell fortunes, find stolen goods, discover hidden treasure, lay spirits, and raise the devil. And his whole art is contained in this little book.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: (Peeping.) By the Lord! she steers well thro' the breaker I was dam'd afraid she had sprung a leak, he pump'd her so hellishly!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: You don't say so, pet?

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: But I do!—you shall hear—I'd just taken the book in my hand, and raised a familiar spirit, to enquire of him if you'd succeed in your undertaking, and he had just risen thro' the floor, when you knock'd at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: (Stares and trembles.) I declare you supprise me! let me get de tings, and I'll go.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: You must not yet, 'tis as much as your life is worth, to touch any thing before I have laid him.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: (Aside.) By my soul! she acts her part well; she'd out-face truth, and out-brazen the devil! a girl after my own heart, damme.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Can you lay him den?—my dear pet.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Why yes!—I've rais'd and laid five hundred in my time.

SP.SPEAKER: Top.
SP.P: (Aside.) That's true enough, my girl! but I'll secure the spit for fear of the worst.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Oh! my dear pet, do lay him den.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Have you courage enough to see him, dear Cooney?

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: No, no, no, no!—dear pet.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: But there no avoiding it now, you'll see him only in part.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Oh! oh! oh! (Trembling) I bish he was gone!

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: (Places Raccoon's back towards the bed.) Stand you here; don't stir an inch, bend your head a little that way, you may shut your eyes—he's visible, but don't be afraid, he shan't hurt you. (She beckons to Topinlift, he comes from under the bed, she meets him and puts an old blue petticoat over his head and shoulders, and reads.) Dunder unt vetter schleemer hoont, ein blixum kindt, rium tenealis amissee. (Topinlift oversets Raccoon, drops the spit, and runs off.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: (Looking frighten'd.) Mercy on me, here am I? Oh! oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Get up, dear Cooney!—did you see him?— you an't hurt I hope, my dear?—let me help you up. (She raises him) don't be frighten'd, he'll trouble you no more, he's a thousand leagues off by this time. (She applies a smlling bottle to his nose, he starts.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Oh! my dear pet! I—I—I nebber was so frighten'd in all my life! is he gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Aye, far enough—didn't you see him go?

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: I hab de glimp of him as he goed by, I tought he did carry away de corner of de house wid him. Oh! oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: (Runs to the bottle, and brings him a dram.) Drink this, dear Cooney, and you'll soon recover your spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: (Trembling, drinks.) Oh! I was'nt not afraid, a—a—only—

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Courage man!—you'll see ten times more before morning!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: I tink he look like de sailor.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: Yes!—why he's the apparition of one of Blackbeard's crew, and as a confirmation that you'll obtain the treasure, he threw, that spit on the floor as he went off.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: (Takes up the spit.) Why dis is de berry spit dat I put under de bed!

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: So much the better, it was a signal to be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Well, I get de pick-ax and de spade, and den I'll go, but I must have dis liddle book to show Mr. Rattletrap.

SP.SPEAKER: Plack.
SP.P: No, no—it's high Dutch, he can't read it. (Takes it from him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: (Goes to the bed and takes the pick-axe and spade.) Now one buss, my dear pet, and den—

DIV1.HEAD: SONG XIV.
DIV1.L: Oh! when I get de welt,
Dat's buried by de mill,
Enjoy long life an helt,
An pleasure at my will.
What store of gold I'l bring,
My lovely pet to dee,
Den none but my poor ting
Shall share de same wid me. Exit Raccoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Plac.
SP.P:
Well,—it's an old saying, and I think a true one:—When poverty comes the door, love flies out at the window. Really I have experienced the truth of it lately, and hadn't it been for Topinlift, and a few transient friends, I shou'd have been in a poor situa∣tion; for I'm sure Raccoon's nothing belonging to him that can please me but his money, and I see very little of that. He pomises mountains of gold! ut I fancy he'll be deceived as well as myself! I'll trust no longer to bare promises, when a woman finds herself deceived, and deprived of most of the comforts of life, she has it always in her power, and she must be a fool, if she don't take her revenge in a way the most pleas∣ing to herself. Sings.
SONG XV.
Sure gold is the fuel that kindles the fire,
And serves for to fan up a woman's desire,
To a fumbling fool that's decrepid and old:
For in all scenes of life, from the great to the little,
The bench, bar and pulpit, it suits to a tittle;
You're surely condemn'd, if you hav'n't the gold.
But if you have money▪ ne'er mind what your cause is,
But tickle their palms and you'll gain their applauses;
No statesman so great, so cunning, and bold,
But will truckle to you, for the sake of your gold;
And shou'd you lack that—you are certainly sold.
But hang this disappointmen!

LG.L: Let women of bus'ness take care of their men,
If one won't suffice them—why, let them have ten.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V. A Room at Mrs. Trushoop's.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Here he cums!—poor sowl!—how magre he looks! I vow to St. Patrick! an I pity him!

DIV3.STAGE: (MRS. TRUSHOOP meeting him with a bowl of punch.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: And was you after wanting me, my deer?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: To be sure an I was, honey, an hares to you my jewel, and sussex to your undertakins, dare! (Drinks.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: I thank you kindly, my deer!—but I don't know what you mane!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Never mind! drink hearty! (Drinks.) Take anudder pull at it, dare! (Drinks again.) Shure! an it's vary good punch.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: By my sowl!—and it is so, it drinks for all the world like nectar-ambrosial! so it does.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Cum give me one of your swate ould fa∣shion kisses, dare! (Kisses him.) troth, an it seems like ould times now, just for all the wurld—let me take off your apern, honey, for shure an you'll have no more 'casion for it after this. (She takes off his apron and throws it from her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Why now, deer!—an what do you mane?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Never mind, sit down, honey! sure an you must be vary hungry?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Indeed, and I am so!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Poor sowl!—Dolly cum hither child.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Here! ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Here, my good child, take the kays an the big market basket, an go your ways an open the pantry, an fetch up them two cowl roast ducks.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus
SP.P: An the capers—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: An the anchobies, an the gammon—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am! (Going.)
(Aside, looking surpris'd.) By my sowl! this looks well on our side!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Come hither girl! an your going without half your arrant; an the packeld sammon, an the horse-raddish, an the cowl roast-beef—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am. (Going.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (Aside.) Augh hoogh! better and better.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Stop girl! I say—don't be in such a hurry, an the kagg of lobsters, the packeld iceters, an the swate-oyl, you know your maaster loves oyl, an it's vary haling to the belly.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: (Smiling aside.) Yes, ma'am—any thing else?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Why yes, hussey! the jarr of olives— the Chaster chaze—the nates-tung, the sous'd rock, the potted pigeons, the apple-pie, the cowl potatoes, the whaskey-jugg, an a hunder'd things more, but do tha first.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: (Smiling aside.) Why ma'am! this big basket won't hold the half of them!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Why then, go an fatch the t'other big bas∣ket, you fool you! have you no contraption?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: (Going and laughing aside.) Hah! hah! hah! Well, I wonder what all this means? for this week past she's been starving him, and now she's going to cram him like a stuff'd turkey! I believe in my con∣science, she's light-headed! Exit Dolly.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Blassings on you, deer! but you're too good. Why now, when you are good, why then you are too good!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P:
No indeed! an indeed! an I an't, I can't be good enuff—fath! an you desarve it all an more too.—Shall I send for some sassages an aggs? an will
you have a nice spare-rib broyl'd, with some apple sauce, honey?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: No fath, deer! I think in my conshence and heres enuff! why now, if I was an allephant, I cou'dn't ate the half of it? so I cou'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trush.
SP.P: Shure, but you must be vary hungry?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Fath! an I am so and more too, but I musn't make a beast of myself for all that! you know, deer!

DIV3.STAGE: (Enter DOLLY, with the two big market baskets heaped up.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: An have you forgot ev'ry thing, girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Why then fatch them in the parler, an lay the damask table cloth on the big table girl, an set i off han'some an nate, your maaster shall sup in the parler, so he shall; an when your done all that, why, go your ways presently, (not just now) an warm my bed vary well, an sprad the curtins, do you hare, I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am. Exit Dolly.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Indeed, my deer! and I'm vary sorry, you give yourself a grate dale of trubble for me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: No, inded honey, an I do not!—an you know I was always plaz'd to see you ate harty.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Yes, my deer—but I forgot it lately!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Well! never mind it dare, I wish you good luck in your undertakins.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: I thank you my deer,—but what wou'd you be after now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Augh, fath!—the trazure, to be shure!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: What trazure?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Cum—cum, don't think to kape it a sacre from me—shure an I know all about it now!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: About what pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Hav'n't I towld you now?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (Aside.) By my sowl! and we're all ruin'd▪ some traytor has blow'd us! Some nonsense in your head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Fath! an it isn't nonsense though—shure an Mrs. Trowell towld me all about it—as how you are going to dig for trazure, an a graite dale more—

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: And how does Mrs. Trowell know?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Fath! an vary well, shure an Trowell towld her all about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh! the book-sworn? oath-breaking dog! oh! the traito! oh! the Judas! Augh! and Trowell and you must do grat pnance for all this. Well, thank God! and I'm not book-sworn!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Trus.
SP.P: No, my dare, no more you arn't; cum, never mind honey, let's go into supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: I'll follow, deer. (Aside.) Augh! the subber-degullion dog! Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI. A Room.
DIV3.STAGE: (Enter DOLLY, with a warming pn, and TERRANCE meeting her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Oh! Terrance—I'm glad you're come! he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: I suppose so! you want me to fatch a bucket of vater, an then kiss you? don't you? say? (Chucking her under the chin.—Kisses her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: No faith! I don't—but here's the devil to pay! he! he! you never saw the like in all your born days!

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: What?—what the devil is it?—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Why you must go and fetch the priest! he! he! master and mistress has made it up, and they're going to be married over again!
Hoot! the girl tawks like a fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: No faith! I don't, the wedding supper's on the table, and she's going to make him eat our two great big market baskets full, all up at once, and faith! I don't know but the baskets in the bargain he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: By my sowl! Dolly but I believe your'e crazy! —or

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: No, I an't!—you fool!—but you can't think, how kind she has been to him, kissing and slobbering his chops about, like all the world—and the Lord? knows what, and treating him with punch—but I watch'd her, and she took care to have the largest share to herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: Fath!—but I believe an you had a large share too, by your tawk.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: No—the devil a drop I got of it!

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: Then your'e humbugging me, arn't you now Dolly?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: No, I an't 'pon honor!—only peep thro' the key-hole, and see what an elegant variety there is, for the wedding supper!

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: Hoot you fool!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Peep thro' here!—can't you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: (Peeps.) Oh! Jasus!—a grate faste by my sowl! —shure enuff!—why there's enuff for the howl Kon∣grass!—an nobody to ate it! the divil burn me!—but I'll have sum of it!—if they don't ate it all! but what the divil's all this for? say Dolly?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: The Lord above knows!—I swear! I don't, no more than a horse!—if I did, I would tell you in∣deed, Terrance.—We shall know more about it to∣morrow, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: The forerunner of anudder dam'd quarrel!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: The devil may care for me!

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: An me too—but sure Dolly, an you can tell us a little more, about the maning of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P:
No faith! I can't—only mistress went over the way this evening, to drink tea with Mrs. Trowell, and presently after, she came running home, quite out of breath, and bawl'd out, like a mad cow, bawling for her calf!—Dolly!—Dolly! three or four times,
(I thought the house had been on fire!—or some de∣velish thing, or, other) and ordered me to put on the tea-kettle, in all haste—and Oh! how she bothered me, she wanted it to boil, before the fire was made,— Lord! how vex'd I was—I could have cut her throat! —"does it boil?—does it boil?—make haste girl!— how long you stay?—what are you poking about?"— (mimicking her) and called me baggage, and trollop, and a hundred bad names, you never heard such a Bil∣lingsgate!—I never was so cursedly vext, and blind∣ed with smoke, in all my life,—and was obliged at last to bring in the tea-kettle as it was, and the devil a boil it boil'd, no more than when I first put it on the fire—so I don't care!

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: An serve her rite too—the owl'd Jazzebel!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: But the beauty of it was, Terrance,—she made me take the two big market baskets, and go down into the cellar, and fetch up every thing there, for master to eat and drink, (faith! I almost broke my back with them, they were so heavy)—and call him out of the shop?—Oh! you never see such a fid∣getting as she made!—

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: I'll warrant the Brimstone made noyse enuff! fath! an she's no slouch at that! let's have anudder peep at um—Augh hoogh! an how he tares away at the roast ducks?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: I don't at all wonder at it—he's almost starv'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: By my sowl!—but this is a queer sort of a re∣velushin—there's something brewing, Dolly! take my word for it, but what are you after wid the wharming-pan?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Why you fool!—what do you think, when people's married? why they're going to bed together after supper, and she ordered me to warm it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: Worse an worse—by my sowl!—but there'll be a grate earthquake to-night! I expact—but you slut you, why you hav'n't been up yet to warm it, an the pans quite cowl'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Faith! I don't care! then let 'em lye the closer, and warm it themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: Hah! hah! hah!— (A noise in the parlour, like mov∣ing of chairs.)

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Oh! gracious—they're coming to bed!—Run Terrance! don't let 'em see you for all the world!— hide yourself in the cow-stable, and when they're gone to bed, we'll partake of the wedding feast.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.P: That's rite Dolly—I'm divilish hungry and dry too!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: I wont forget you, fly you devil!—fly! they are here. Exit Terrance.

DIV3.STAGE: (Enter MR. and MRS. TRUSHOOP, with a candle, meeting DOLLY.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: An have you now, warm'd the bed well girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes ma'am, very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: And sprad the Kurtins?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Then go your ways, an clare the table, an put out the fire, and lock the dure, an go your ways bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Where's Terrance?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Gone to bed ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: How long first?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Two hours ago ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: How cum that?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: He said he was sleepy ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Trus.
SP.P: Vary well, go your ways.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes ma'am, (Aside) blatherum, lolling out her tongue and Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. The place of action, nar the Mill and Stone-bridge.
DIV3.STAGE: (Scene opens and discovers RATTLETRAP dress'd in his ma∣gic habit, with a dark lanthorn and candle, QUADRANT, with a magnet, rod, and wand, &c. &c. &c. an old iron bound chest, and SPIFIRE, with a copper figure, represent∣ing the head and shoulders of BLACKBEARD.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Well done Spitfire! the hole I see is made.

SP.SPEAKER: Spit.
SP.P: Yes—yes—I've not been idle, since you left me.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: (Aside) He's the very plan of a fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: (Aside) Not his fellow to be found—He has per∣formed wonders!—But we must lose no time, (looks at his watch) 'tis near eleven o'clock. (They poke in the chest, stones, brickbatts, broken bottles, and two or three rusty looking pieces of silver.)

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: Come! come! let's bury it at once. (All assist, and bury the chest.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: (To Spitfire) Now we've nothing more to do, at present, than to see you descend into your subterranity —step down!—step down! and mind when I give the signal, throw fire-balls, and when they come to a sight of the chest, push up the figure, and act as I have be∣fore directed you—Now be sure you act the devil, as if you were going to deceive the devil himself, and we'll reward you devilishly well.

SP.SPEAKER: Spit.
SP.P: And the devil take me if I don't! (Spitfire goes down the hole, and takes the figure, lanthorn, and candle with him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: Now every thing is ready to receive them, and if our devil plays his part well—I think, we shall have a devilish merry night of it. He! he! he!—egad here's some of 'em coming! (They halloo without, Canoe! Canoe! those within answer, Canoe! Canoe!)

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Where are the mud-mongers?

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: They're just at hand, we heard them, as we came down the hill. (Different voices without hallooing Canoe! Canoe! Canoe! Canoe! &c. those within answering Canoe! &c.)

DIV3.STAGE: (Enter WASHBALL, TRUSHOOP, BUCKRAM, RAC∣COON and TROWELL, with pick-axes, spades, shovels, spit, and ANDRA FERRARA shouldered.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: I tore my shins unaccountably, coming thro' the briers!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Fath! and I tumbled up the hill, 'till I got my futt in the boggs, and if I hadn't held fast by the vater, I'd be drown'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum and Quad.
SP.P: Hah! Hah! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Don't mind, gentlemen, what is de tore skin, or de cold foot, compar'd wid de prospect of dese riches?

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: By me saul! mon—and I chearg'd mesel we twa bottles to Ieeghten me nawse, and thats a bonny guede in a dark neeght, and for fear o meeting we ony skoondrels, Ize feetch'd me Andra we me, as gude stuff as e're wa made in a scoteland!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Well gentlemen, I see we're all here, don't let us waste time, let's be serious; keep silence! by the calculation I made this morning, by the Satellites, the treasure must be near this place, (He takes an observation, and works his magnetic hazel-rod) the magnet works this way —

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: I tought so.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Lave off your botheration!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Pray be silent! it draws excessive strong this way. I feel myself interrupted by in visibles! I can scarcely keep the rod in my hands, there! now I have it! it draws this way!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Dis is de berry place, gentlemen!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: And can't you now be azey, and howl'd your tung? you fool! you know nothing about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh! dear! what interruptions?

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Not a word! not a word! pray be silent! I'm near the place, the rod points to this spot—I'm near the centre, I know the rod to be true, I've tried its virtue, 'twas cut on All-hallows eve, at 12 o'clock at night, with my back to the moon, and the mercury injected while the sap was running.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (Aside) By the holy stone! but I believe, he was born in the moon!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: (Draws a large circle with his wand, and says) Dia∣paculum interrav, tenebrossitas stravaganza! (Goes round the circle, and sticks twelve pieces of iron-wire in the Periphery; each piece having a bit of paper cut out in the form of a star on its head—as he sticks them down, he names the twelve signs of the Zodiac.) Aries, Taurus, Germini, Can∣cer, Leo, Virgo, Libra, Scorpio, Sagitarius, Capriconi∣us, Aquarius, Pisces, make no noise else you'll dis∣turb Jupiter, who is the most wakeful planet, and is now in his first sleep. (He puts on a large pair of spectacles) Let me see! its now 12 o'clock, Jupiter in a sound sleep, a good omen! (He calls WASHBALL, TRUSHOOP, BUCK∣RAM, RACOOON, and TROWELL.) Take off your coats and jackets, (they pull them off) now stand within the cir∣le, (he places HUM, QUADRANT, and PARCHMENT, without the circle, at different posts, and says) now keep a good look out, Canoe's the word, so don't forget it.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (Aside) The devil a forget, myself will forget! fath! and I will sooner forget my prayers!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Now run down the spit and try this place—Mr. Washball.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Thurst down the spit, and says) Oh dear! it's very soft and slushey.

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Never mind! the better digging,—try it again, I kw its the identical spot!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Softer and softer, I feel it! I feel it! it strikes against something!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Then fall too all hands, and dig, and when the watch-word is given, fall flat on the ground. (They dig, he views the stars) now the Dragons head and the Scor∣pion's tail are in conjunction. Castor's in the wane, Procyon is stationary, but Sagitarius seems obnubilat∣ed, and fast approaching to a state of obtenebration! hah! I don't like that! it rather looks inauspicious and portentous of ill!—but Syrius's right foot—

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: (Without) Canoe! (They answer Cance! and fall down within the circle. A fiddle is heard at a distance, play∣ing badly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Inferno atum, gastro fagnum!—Rise and go on! 'twas nothing but a blind drunken fidler, and some company returning from Batchelors-hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: By my sowl! now, and I've made a swate packle of my self, all over full of mud! Augh! and I had the spawlpene here an I'd give him two or three handfulls of bothers wid my shelaley, so I wou'd'nt.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Deel tak me mon! but I dinna leke this, 'tis a foul drumlie pleece, gin I a wa we him, I'ze claw the tyke a wee bit, and brok his damn'd feedle!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Ah me!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Not a word gentlemen! proceed, (they dig) but Syrius's right foot, over Orion's left shoulder, looks well, and the Swan's tail near the Hydra's heart, has a promising appearance. (One fire-ball, the diggers fright∣en'd, and attempt to run out of the circle.) Don't stir an inch! if you break the mounds, I've no power!—dig! dig! Conjabetima, morentium habavo, omnibusque contubernalium! and this leap-year is not unfavora∣ble. (Another fire-ball, with a roaring below, at which they are terrified.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (Aside.) Augh! how my hart bates!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Come near Mr. Rattletrap! Oh! dear! Oh! dear! I shall faint!

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: I'd give all my share, I had never come! mercy on me!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Oh! Oh!—I wish I was at home, I nebber wou'd come again!

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Hoot! canna ye a be queeit?

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Never fear! I'll protect you!—Hobonos cum verigos, omne croxibus influvientum! dig! dig! (view∣ing the stars) but yet certain appearances, puts me to a stand, baffles my utmost skill, and indicates an in∣fernal opposition! I'll try my Omphaloptic glass. Aye! now I discover the cause of the opposition! I now distinctly perceive, thro' a boundless radiant ap∣perture, the tail of a huge Comet! like a monstrous, overgrown ram-cat, with his hind legs, kicking and scratching the Planets and Stars about, as tho' they were marbles or snow-balls! strange Phenomenon! a glorious opportunity this would be, for a young divine, to study Astro-Theology! one peep thro' this, would instantaneously and eternally silence, the whole host of sceptics!
SP.L: "Fierce meteors shoot their arbitrary light
And Comets march with lawless horrors bright!"

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: (Without) Canoe! (All answer Canoe! and fall down.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Metantaborabulum, exultissimo ocabulum mongrabo! Rise! it was nothing but an old cow passing along! go on! (All rise and dig.)

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Damn the Hawkie for a dorty beech! wha the deel does she want here? does she tak us for Bulls an be damn'd to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Arra deer! and how my wife will scowld, when I fatch her the money, for spileing my new brogues.

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P:
Sagitarius is now clear, and the Orb of the
Moon, is in contact with Jupiter, good! Sextile in con∣junction with Quartile right! (He waves his wand) Sa∣turn is a metallic planet, and tho' in common the most dull, is now perfectly pellucid, and out shines even Venus herself! this is the best sign of all! (Another fire∣ball, a roaring below.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh! dear! Oh dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Oh! Oh! Oh!—what shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: Defend us! defend us!—Mr. Rattletrap!— Oh!—

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: These invisibles will disturb you awhile, now your just upon it. Conjunction, oppositorium, placabulum fomoso!—dig away! Arcturus now appears, Constel∣latione planetarium! Venus is now the morning star, and is eclipsed four digits. (Two or three fire-balls, and a roaring below, the diggers terrified.) Now their rage in∣creases! we'er near the treasure, don't be afraid, I am with you, their fiery darts will soon be over, dig! dig! Cummeritantibus considerationibus, terrabandum op∣hagnum!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh!—Oh!—Oh!—

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Quut mon! quut! wha the deel cares for em, dig mon! dig!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Oh!—Oh!—what will become of us?

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P:
Stick to it!—Stick to it! (They dig.) These noc∣turnal observations, sometimes deceive the brightest astronomers! the whole planetary system now changes and appears to have a centrifugal motion—now whirls within a huge vortex, with a velocity, beyond the pow∣er of mathematics to calculate, now orbicular! now circumvolves! and Georgium Sidus, forms an obtuse angle, whose Hypothenuse seems offuscated, or eclips∣ed by the horns of the Moon, and whose perpendicular is geocentric with our earth! these appearances are new to me—beyond my Talismanic powers to com∣prehend! preternatural! utterly uncogitable! In
short, I have never experienced such a rare Synchro∣nism, since I have had any knowledge of the Occult sciences! however I now perceive a ray of hope! Hic∣cius Doccius! now Cassiopaea and the Bears-tail, are on the meridian! excessive lucky!

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: (Aside) He performs to admiration!

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: (Aside) Incomparably well, by Jupiter! He! he! he! (Two or three fire balls, and an increase of roaring be∣low.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Mercy on me! I shall faint—Oh! oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Haud up mon!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: O my poor ting, I wish I had stay'd wid you!

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: I tremble every joint of me. O Lord! oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (Aside) Fath! and my knees tump togedder, like a pare of pot-hooks, but I won't tell um for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Gentlemen!—summon up all your courage! —don't be pusillanimous! dig! dig!—the enemy's fire is nearly exhausted!—Tincturum, corrosivum, subli∣matum! (Takes an observation.)

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: (Without, aside.) Come let's drink while the fools are digging. He! he! he! (They drink, and point, and laugh at the diggers.) Poisonous exhalations rise from this de∣vilish swamp! I'm afraid old Washball will get the Cholera-morbus. He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: (Without, aside.) I'm rather of opinion he'll get the Perip-no-money. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: (Without, aside.) By the Lord Harry! that's well said! I'm entirely of your opinion—no money. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P:
Every thing now looks well! fine appearances! Spica, south eleven degrees fifty eight minutes, good! to-morrow is Sexagesima sunday, good! Lyra, south, sets nine minutes after one this morning, good! the horns of the moon in Apogee, good! Bull's-eye rises, good again! Venus rises, very good! she sets S. West obliquely towards the mines of Mexico and Peru, ex∣cellent!
In short! the macrocosm of the whole visi∣ble system of nature, are strongly in our favor! a cer∣tain sign of success! occidental! occidental! glori∣ous!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (Aside) By St. Patrick! but I swatt swately!— by my sowl! now but its harder work than digging pa∣rates!

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: (Aside) Only see how it drops off me! I wish it was all over.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (Aside) It's good for your helt, you devil you. Fath! and I would be very sorry, but I had one good drink of whiskey just now my deer.

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Have a little patience! the bull's eye is this moment stationary and opacous! it would prove fatal to drink now! it would most assuredly bring on the Hydrophobia! dig! dig! before the eclipse comes on! our success altogether depends upon your industry, one second of time now well employ'd, is worth a whole year! go on! go on! redouble your vigilance!

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: (Aside, without) Let's give 'em another tumble in the mud.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: (Without, aside) With all my heart,—he! he! —Canoe! (The diggers answer Canoe! and fall down.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Facinorum, muddum, dashum, splashum. Rise and go on! it was nothing but a distant barking of dogs. (Viewing the stars.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh dear! I can't support it any longer! it will kill me! indeed it will! these cursed dog days are co∣ming fast upon us!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: By my sowl and you're right—fath an they bark all night long in our alley!—O Jasus! and what a packle I'm in?

SP.SPEAKER: Hum, Parch. and Quad.
SP.P: (Without, aside) Hah! hah! he! he! (alternately.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P:
Benedictum, atmosphericum! hold out only six minutes, three quarters and the 197th part of a minute
and we have it! (Pointing to the stars with his wand) luck∣ily for us! the star Wormwood (as mentioned in the Revelations) is in a state of occultation! Mars ap∣proaching omnolency! and Bacchus as drunk as a pi∣per, success is certain! (Fire-balls and a terrible roaring.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh! I'm dead! I'm dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: I'll soon vivificate you! here, take a little A∣qua me Rabulus, it cost me half a crown a spoonful. (He drinks it off.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Stop! stop! don't drink it all!

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: You needn't halloo to him, don't you know a man can't hear whil he's drinking?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Fath 'an I never know'd that before! by my sowl next time I'll be up wid him, and I'll halloo, stop, stop you devil you, afore he begins.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: That's reeght mon!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: How it revives the animal spirits?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: The devil burst you, and that's all the harm I wish you!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: (Aside) Ha! ha!— (Looks at his watch) the time's just expired—pray be serious! dig away! dig away! now for your lives! I feel the ground move under my feet!—the treasure is struggling, it wants to be re∣lieved from it's long imprisonment, dig!—dig!— Theophrasticum, Privilegium! now the whole host of devils are pulling against us, and levelling all the darts of infernal fury at us!

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: I feel the chest!—I feel the chest!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: I see it! I see it!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Ne plus ultra! up with it, up with it▪ all's our own! (The ghost appears and spits fire, the diggers with uplifted hands, looking at it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: How he squints.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: The deel me care! troth mon an he looks leke auld Squintefego at Aberdeen!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P:
Fath an he squints sure enuff, but no more
than a gentleman ought to squint, but I've a grate mind to wauk off wid myself, for the devil burn me▪ but I believe he'll burn us all up, by my soul! and he's no slouch of a fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Troth mon!—he cuts a shacking figure!

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: He's got a beard like a ram-goat, and a nose like a bald-eagle!—see! see how he knits his brows!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh by my sowl, and he shan't brow bate, me!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: He has truly a Colossean stature! a terrific ap∣pearance, and a belligerous phiz! but I'll manage him for all that! (The ghost continues to spit fire; with fire-balls and a roaring below. All kneel down.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: O! what an old sinner I have been—I've brought myself into a sad scrape! Mea culpa—

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Pray in English! pray in English! dese pirate spirits don't understand de latin. (He lifts up his hands, and says) O! O! I don't know what to say.—O! O! I wish I hab lib'd a better life; do Mr. Washball say your prayers!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Dirrige, nos domine! I can't pray in English, do you say something good to it. Oh! Mr. Rattle∣trap, I'm dead! I'm dead. Oh! Oh! (The fire-balls and roaring continues.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: Lord! have mercy upon us, and keep this de∣vil from us! O! how my heart goes pit-a-pat? enough to break the Perricardum!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Cruciblarum, Advansum! Perrilorum! (The ghost disappears; they rise.) He's almost conquer'd now! (The ghost appears again; spits fire with fire-balls; a terrible roaring below, they tremble and fall on their knees again.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P:
Right worshipful master, no—As it was in de beginning—no, no, what is your name? Raccoon, who gib you dat name? my grand-moder and god-fader, no dats wrong—Our fader—I can't say it! Oh! Oh!
Oh! for eber and eber, Amen. Dare he comes, dare he comes again!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (To Raccoon.) Lave off you black-mout! you havn't it, (he says) Pater-noster, mea culpa, Sinner∣rum, helpum, deliverum, misserabulum, tuscarorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: By me saul mon! 'tis the deel himsel! Ize see his claven foot!— (Aside.) Troth and he makes me quack too, a wee-pickle!

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: Save us! Save us! from his fiery jaws! he's seeking whom he may devour.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh! and if he swallows me, by my sowl! and I'll kick his guts out in the twinkling of a broom∣stick!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh! Oh! save me!—save me too!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: (To the ghost) Superiorum, lakeavi, hurorum! (The ghost disappears) now's the lucky minute, the Ser∣pent's-neck, is round the Poleaster! Raise the chest, (They rise, the ghost appears, and spits fire, with fire-balls, the roaring below increases, the diggers shrieking and trembling, those without laugh at them.) Now, gentlemen, raise the chest, banish fear! keep fast! (he calls to those without) your assistance gentlemen or we lose all! should it sink now, it's irrecoverably lost! not all the magicians of Egypt, nor the witch of Endor cou'dn't recover it! quick gentlemen! quick! nows the interesting mo∣ment!
SP.L: "There is a tide in the affairs of men,
"Which if taken at the flood, leads on to fortune."
SP.P: up with it.
SP.STAGE: (They run and assist in raising the chest.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: (Looking towards the ghost.) Dats Old Blackbeard himself! by de birtue and de power of de free and de accepted mason, to me gibben, (here he gives the free-mason's sign, or something like it) I command you to depaa! Oh! Oh! Oh what disturbs dy poor soul from rest?

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Horrificatabus, Profundum, Horridumque, Spec∣taculum, Demonium.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Haud faust, dinna quut yere grup, (he steps to∣wards the ghost) noo I'ze ken him, I'ze gang after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Pray don't Mr. Buckram, it be de pirate ap∣parition, did'n't you see how bery angry he look at me, when I did speak to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: The devil be from me, and I believe its Doctor Foster!

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: The deel ma care, wha he be, Doctor Faustus, spirit, apparition, Backbeard, or the deel himsel, gin he con stond a cut o me Andra, he mun be the deel in troth. (He takes up his broad sword, runs towards the ghost, makes a cut at it, and falls down; the ghost disappears for a short time; eturns again spitting fire, the roaring continues more violent. Buckram lies on the ground, and says) Deil tak a warlocks I say, I ha leek to ha brok my neeke down the brae!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: By my sowl! and you'd like to make a Somer∣sault of i! fath! and Ricketts is a nincompoop to you honey!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat
SP.P: (Aside) Ha! ha! ha! a comical dog.—That was a very impetuous, temerarius step! didn't you know he's invulnerable? if I hadn't been here, you would have been incinerated, for your presumption. (He steps up to the ghost, and says) Horridum, Callefridum, Bus∣cantivo, Interdenabulum! thus far will I permit thee to come, ut no farther. Avaunt! Avaunt! Avaunt! and be thou laid in Lake Huron! 'till the waters there∣of be exhausted! (The ghost disappears, with a dreadful noise) now we're all safe! Consummatum et Trium∣phicatibus! up with the chest! those fiends of darkness will trouble us no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P:
(Rises up and shakes himself.) The deel a seeght mare, ye'ell ha o him noo he's gatten a smell o me
Andra! (they hoist up the chest, some black rusty pieces of silver tumble out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Now our toils are over, and we have caught our prey.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Huzza! huzza! huzza! &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Greedily taking up one of the pieces of silver, kisses it and says) Oh! my dear! my dear! (he rubs it and takes it to the lanthorn.) Let me see— (puts on his spectacles) One Thousand, Sixteen Hundred and Eighty Four, aye! aye! this is the very money, that Blackbeard got at Panama, when he robb'd the churches! Oh! the poor priests! the poor priests! It seems very providentially to have fallen into my hands! Come! come! let's take it away, before day-light appears.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: May we presume to take it away, Mr. Rat∣tletrap?

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Jubileetatebusque!—Finis cum fistulum, po∣pulorum jigg!—my business is finished, therefore all's our own! away with it!

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: There's one thing proper first to mention, gentlemen, my sister from whom I received the in∣formation, and to whom we are all so much indebted for this lucky turn of good fortune, is entitled to a share; besides, I think she highly merits a handsome gratuitous present, as an acknowledgment of our gra∣titude to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: No, brudder Hum, I tink she's titled to no more den half de share, she's no more den de woman. But, what do you mean by de present?

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: A whole share! I insist upon it, is her just due! but, as for the present, that must be left to your generosity, and I dare answer you'll not be wanting in munificence! what think you of one of the boxes of diamonds, or some such trifle?

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: By all means!

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: Little enough in all conscience!

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: I think so indeed! I would add one of the boxes of pearls to it!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Lord! Lord! no, no; I protest against a share and a present too! we shall be ruin'd! ruin'd! Mr. Raccoon: indeed we shall, speak to 'em, do sir, do!

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Damme mon! but I thin the lassie deserves em a, an mare too!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Consider! gentlemen, we hab run de risk of our libes wid dese spirits! besides, what will de wo∣man do wid so much of de dimonts, and de oder tings?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Aye, indeed! I say the diamonds truly! why they are of more value than all the rest of the things together! why you are all going mad!—mad!—mad! —indeed you are!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Fath an! she shall have um all for me! and more too! by my sowl! but I believe and you want 'um all yourself to hang up at your shop-winder, to make paple think how you're a toot-drawer, and don't you now, honey?

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P:
Gentlemen, I'm surprized! nay, almost pe∣trified, at this sudden change of sentiments you have now expressed! you, who before you were possessed of this immense▪ treasure, entertained such lofty and laudable ideas of ambition, philanthropy and genero∣sity! you, who were for purchasing titles, building and endowing hospitals and the Lord knows what! I say, gentlemen, I am astonish'd beyond measure at the change. Can it be possible! that you, who are now in actual possession of this treasure, you so ardently wished for; and I say, gentlemen, on the attainment of which your pious resolutions were sounded, should so suddenly change and turn traitors to that heaven-born
virtue, gratitude! and that Satan, that malig∣nant, malicious, malevolent, mischievous, unpropiti∣ous, pestilential, pestiferious, envious, spiteful, un∣grateful devil! could so suddenly transform you into such Judases, as even that most avaricious of all de∣vils! Mammon himself! would blush at, hang down his head, and be ashamed of. I must not! I cannot believe it!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Mighty fine talk indeed! but its nothing but wind!

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: Come, come! let's give the poor woman a full share, and the diamonds and all; if it hadn't been for her we shou'dn't have had a copper!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: No, no! I forbid it!—I protest against it!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: (Aside) Hoot you owld brute.

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: Let's put it to a vote?

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: That's right! and should that fail I protest! I'll give my whole share to my sister, and phillippic them to petrifaction!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: (Aside, To Washball.) Who de debil's dis Phi∣lip Pick?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Aside) I suppose some ruffian of a fellow! he's going to set upon us to way-lay, rob and mur∣der us!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: (Aside.) Yes, I tink so too! Dad I'll always carry my pistols in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: Vote! vote! (They vote and carry it for a full share, and a present of a box of diamonds and a box of pearls.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Fath an I'm glad of it!

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Gentlemen, I'm satisfy'd! and I heartily thank you in my sister's name.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: I tink its a bery great shame!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh, dear!—we're ruin'd!—we're ruin'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: The day approaches; remove it immediately!

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: Where shall we carry it?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: There's a cunning place in my house, I'll take care of it! it will be safe! I'll sleep on it all night!

SP.SPEAKER: All say.
SP.P: Agreed!—agreed!

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Now gentlemen, let's all meet precisely at six o'clock this morning and divide it. I think some of us shou'd assist Mr. Washball; as this chest contains an immense treasure, we can't be too careful; he's aged, and some unlucky circumstance may intervene.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: No, no, I can take care of it, well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Dat's right, brudder Hum, I tink I'd better go too, as I understand de military. If we should be at∣tack, my service may be necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: Very true! and if Mr. Trowell, Mr. Trus∣hoop, and Mr. Buckram will attend you, it will be the safer.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: The devil burn Trushoop, if he forsakes it!

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Deel tak the mon, that lags beheend!

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Well gentlemen! I think this great success, de∣serves a song; come bear chorus!

SP.SPEAKER: All say.
SP.P: With all my heart.

LG.L: Tho' my art some despise, I appeal to your eyes,
For a proof of my magical knowledge,
Tho' the wisdom of schools, damn our art and our tools,
We can laugh at the fools of the college.
Chorus. We can, &c.
Now my friends we're possest, of the glorious chest,
Join hands and rejoice beyond measure,
Let it be our first care, that great blessing to share;
Whose contents, are an infinite treasure!
Chorus. Whose, &c.

SP.P: Now gentlemen bear off your prize!

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Tak hauld Trowell, I'ze hurt me shouther in the fa' i' gat down the brae. I canna carry't lad! (The dupes take up the chest, and bear it off guarded by the humorists.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: It feels brave and ponderous.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: That's true for you!—fath! I woud'nt care if I break my back wid it. Arra deer! tread of my heels.

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: I beg your pardon!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Fath▪ an your very welcome—for the devil burn me, if I care for my heels at all, at all,—so I don't!— (Exeunt omnes, Buckram brings up the rear, flourish∣ing his broad sword, capering and singing a Scotch air.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, II. A room in Washball's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Bless me! How could you venture (after the severe reproof my uncle gave you,) to approach this house, at this late hour of the night?

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P: Love! angelic love! which knows no fear but your displeasure, hath brought me here on eagle's wings, to waft you hence, and seal that vow, already ratified in heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: But consider my dear Meanwell, what may be the consequence of such a rash step, when, perhaps a few days perseverance, may bring it to a conclusion, with his consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P: I cannot think of trusting to any thing so pre∣carious, and as he has already consented, by being my bondsman for the licence, and publicly declared his as∣sent, we shall be looked upon by the honest, virtuous, and judicious, as sufficiently justified in taking this step.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: I am confounded! my love to you spurs me to a slight! but my duty to my uncle, commands me to wait his reconciliation. I know not what to do, or, what to say!

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P: Haste! haste my dear Lucy! the precious mo∣ments are swiftly passing! each moment seems an hour 'till we're one, the clergyman waits, (with chosen friends) to tie the nuptial knot, and crown our bliss!

LG.L: My throbbing heart must now give way
To love, to honor, and obey.
Lo! Hymen's torch is lighted.
Lo! Hymen's, &c.
My heart! my all!—I now resign,
O! Meanwell!—Meanwell!—I'll be thine,
In wedlock's bands united!
In wedlocks, &c.
Of Venus' charms, let poets write!
Diana chaste, or, Juno bright!
Of Kitty, Doll, or, Susey!
Of Kitty, &c.
The charms of all, are center'd here,
In Lucy!—charming Lucy dear!
Haste! haste! my lovely Lucy!
Haste, &c.

DIV3.STAGE: They go off quick, hand in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P:
I can't bear the thoughts of dividing, not I! division! why I cou'd never learn it at school! but, addition and multiplication, were always my darlings! Two hundred and fifty thousand pounds, divided into nine parts, let me see—aye! I have it! nine times nine is, a, a, sixty-two, no, that's wrong. Nine times eleven is, a, a hundred and six, and four over, no that's too much, but I'm no scholar, never mind, no matter,
I can count a hundred as fast as any of 'em, and they can't cheat me! Charity begins at home, and he must be the greatest fool on earth, that cheats himself; I never could forgive my self for such a sin as that, I think I am old enough to have more wit. He that cheats another, can wipe off the sin, by restoring four-fold, but he that cheats himself; poor soul! the sin will lie at his own door, and it will never be in his power to make himself restitution! no, no, I know better; that must be the crying, that is spoken of by Lazarus, Nicodemus, Judas, or some other prophet, I forget who now; alack! its many years ago, since I read the bible, no matter. I'll e'en go and inform the Collec∣tor, then I shall have one half to myself, and the other will go the President of the United States. They'll call me traitor and informer, but I don't care, let them laugh that wins, ha! ha! It's an old saying and a true one, aye, I have it! "One bird in hand is better far, than two that's in the bush,"—no, no, "than two that in bushes are." Aye, that's it! I remember it's so on my neighbour Simmond's sign, I love to make rhimes, when they jingle so cleverly, but here's two hundred and fifty thousand birds in the cage, and most of them pretty yellow birds! Oh! they'll make delightful mu∣sic, and make me sing too! I mus'n't lose any time, no, inded! (He looks up) I think this is the house, aye! (knocks at the door several times, and call▪) Mr. Collector! Mr Collector! (Collector appears at the window, in his shirt and night-cap.)

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Who's there! and what's your urgent business, disturbing my rest so soon in the morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Why, why sir, its business of very great im∣portance!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Importance, or not, I think you might have stay'd 'till day light.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: I coud'n't sir—indeed I coud'n't!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I'm not us'd to have my rest broke, at this un∣seasonable hour!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Sir, sir!—we'll satisfy you handsom'ly for this extraordinary inconvenience!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: (Aside.) That's speaking to the point!—Oh! very well!—very well!—what is the business, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Why, why, sir! I have an information, to lay before you, concerning a chest of treasure—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: A chest of treasure? sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Yes! sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: A chest of treasure? I don't understand you, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Aside) The deuce you dont? the fellow's stu∣pid.—I say, a chest of treasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Explain yourself, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: 'Tis already explain'd!—I tell you, sir! it's a chest of treasure that we dug out of the ground last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Last night!—where?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Why, why, somewhere—but I hav'n't time to tell you now. Come down! sir—pray come!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: What! a large chest?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Aside) What a fool he is. Yes! a large chest and very heav: I know I help'd to carry it, and it almost kill'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Why, how long is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Why, why! six foot long; as long as a coffin, (aside) and when it's emptied, I wish you were buried in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Can you be serious, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P:
(Aside.) This fellow will exhaust all my pa∣tience. Yes, yes! I am, I am! myself and several others are concerned in it, and it grieves my con∣science to cheat the President out of his lawful right; so, pray sir, seize it, seize it, instantly, for me and
the President. I expect all concerned will be at my house directly to open and share it. Come, make haste sir, do!—Put the broad P on it, and then we shall be safe: you must act for me and the President, and we'll reward you handsomely.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I'm afraid you're too sanguine, and it's all de∣ception!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Aside) What a cursed fool he is!—No! no! it an't, it an't; it's a real fact! here's occular demon∣stration! for this piece of money, (shewing the piece) dropt out of the chest when we took it out of the ground. Look here, sir! see it! see it!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Say you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: True, sir, true! pray be expeditious, do sir, do, I insist upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Well sir!—since you insist upon it, I mu seize it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: I do! I do! my fidelity to the United States, obliges me to insist upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Remember your promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: We'll satisfy you, nobly.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I shall look to you alone, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Very well! very well! I'll be your paymas∣ter. (Aside) Since you're afraid to trust my part'ner. Come down, sir! do, do.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I'll wait on you instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: He's cursedly afraid of trusting my part'ner. Ha! ha! ha! I shall soon let him know what a servant he has; a dilatory, suspicious dog! I'll have him turn∣ed out, as sure as he was put in. (Collector enters the street.) This way, sir! this way. Follow me, sir! quick! quick! or we shall be too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Lead on, sir! lead on. (Exeunt.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. A Room in WASHBALL's House.
DIV3.STAGE: (Scene opens and discovers TRUSHOOP, RACCOON, TROW∣ELL, and BUCKRAM, itting on a chest, and OLD GA∣BRIEL standing by.)

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: Gabriel, where's your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Just stepp'd out.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Will he be in soon?

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Ave—may be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: Oh!—here he comes, but who the devil's that with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: The collector! egad! This is what I didn't expect. (Aside.) It will not do to dupe him, we must let him into the secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Leave that to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: (Takes the collector aside and says) Sir, I am sorry you have been put to this trouble; it's a scheme of diversion only; please not to notice it; I'll acquaint you with the whole history of it when it is concluded.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: (Aside) Ha! ha! Just as I thought knowing your funny character.—Mr. Hum, your servant—gentlemen yours. (Going.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Sir! sir! stay, pray do your duty!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Sir,—its an affair too intricate for me at pre∣sent, I must first advise with the States Attorney Ge∣neral.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash
SP.P: You shan't go!—I insist upon it, I charge you in the President's name, seize it! seize it!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I must first have advice, then I'll return again.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: I forbid you to go at your peril! I'll inform the President, and you shall be hang'd for not doing your duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I can't help that! (Ext.)— (Washball attempts to go after him, they stop him and he bawls.) Let me alone! let me alone!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh!—you cursed owld traytor, arn't you asham'd now, to be chating us after this way?

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: I never heard of such another villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: O Lord,—oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: (Aside) There's queer doings here.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Ye enfemous auld skoodre! ye turn'd een∣former, and states-evedence, to get the ane alf till yere sel, but yere oot noo, troth and I'ze a mine to leeghten yere heed by ane o yere luggs.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: (Aside) Worse and worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: O Lord,—oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: What did you tink, we are all fools to be cheat∣ed by you?

SP.SPEAKER: Hum.
SP.P: Nothing can equal this! open the chest, who knows but the States-attorney may be on our backs immediately?

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: Had I suspected this before, I could have sum∣mon'd a whole host of infernals, to have carried him away in a whirl-wind.

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: 'Tis a pity ut you had, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Arra my deer! and give me a little bit of an der, and I'll fatch 'um in a jiffin.

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P: I shall have no more power, Mr. Trushoop, 'till the moon changes.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Fath, an I'm sorry for that honey.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: O Lord,—oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: A traitor and an informer, gentlemen, of all mankind, are the most despicable of all wretches; you see gentlemen, the turpitude of that old curmudgeon's heart; after his most solemn oath of secrecy and ho∣nesty, he thinks nothing of betraying his best friends, (Judas like) and his own soul, for the sake of his body! without the least regard for a sacred and solemn oath!

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: (Aside) How he abuses my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Quad.
SP.P: Mr. Trushoop where's your adz? open the chest.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh my deer, and here we are, bote at your sharviss.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Strives to prevent him, and call.) Mr. Collector! M. Collector!

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Stand off, you old slubberdegullion, (opening the chest, Hum, Parchment, Quadrant, and Rattletrap, holding Washball, he struggles to get from them, and bawls out) where's the Collector? where's the Collector? touch it at your perils, you villains! I'll swear robbery against you! help Gabriel, help!

SP.SPEAKER: Gab
SP.P: (Aside) Lack-a-day, I believe they're going to rob my maste! I would help him with all my heart, but my scuffling days are all over long ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Parch.
SP.P: Go on with your business gentlemen,—open the chest.— (Trushoop, Trowell, Raccoon, and Buckram open the chest.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Touch it at your peril, I say. It belongs to me and my partner.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Belongs to the devil, you tif—we'll soon see who'll fae the sharing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: (Aside) I never see the like before.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Help—help!—murder—murder—fire—thieves —Betty, Betty, bring down the bags you made —Run Gabriel for the Collector! Oh, oh, I'm just dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: Yes, I wil, and the Constable too. Sorrow on me, but I believe they'll murder my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Dare! de chest opens. (They let Washball go, he runs towards the chest, the dupes all striving to get their shares.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Give me my share!—give me my share.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: The devil a copper you tief.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P:
The deel a bawbie, ye shall ha' mon.— (In the scuff they overset the chest, push down Washball, and out tum∣ble
the contents, the dupes looking at each other confused.)

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Hoo mon—wha the deel's a this?—naething but stanes!—I ken we'll enaugh, wha it is—deil damme, but I'ze ha'gentelman's satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: De tivel—dis de scheme of brudder Hum. I se∣cond your resolution, do you gib de chalenge Mr. Buckram.

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: Oh mercy!— (Exit Hum, Parchment, Quadrant, and Rattletrap.)

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh hough!—fath, and we're all humbugged.

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: Its all a cheat.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh! but this will be my heart breaking—by my sowl! and I've been made a fool for the future,— but I'll take care for the time to cum.

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: I didn't tink brdder Hum wou'd serve me so, but dad I'll inform de Lodge of dis—dare's Rattle∣trap too wid his stars and tings,—plague on dem all— and hab Mrs. Placket made de fool of me too, wid her conjur-book? I tink it can't be so nader, for she lobes me, or she wou'dn't call me her Cooney—cock-a-pigeon—cock-a-dandy, and all de fine tings, dad I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh! I'm cheated—I'am abus'd, and made a fool of—I shall die, Oh! dear I shall die! (lifting up his hands) "poor Washball, disappointed Washball."

SP.SPEAKER: Gab.
SP.P: (Looking surpris'd with his hands clench'd, aside.) What's all this! alack-a-day. (Hum, Parchment, Quad∣rant, and Rattletrap, peeping alternately, call Canoe!— Washball chasing them, and endeavoring to strike them with his ane,) "get out of my house you villains," (Canoe!) "you dogs," (Canoe!) "you hell-hounds," (Canoe!) "O dear! O dear, I shall faint," (Canoe!) I'm dead! I'm dead," (he sits down) "Oh, Oh, Oh, (Canoe!) they laugh, and run off.

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: A miserable disappointment.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Augh! fath and its all over now—this is the devils own works, and they're the devil's own chil∣dren—and by my sowl, and they'll do grate pannance for all this.— (Sings.)

DIV1.HEAD: SONG XVIII. To be Sung slow.

LG.L: Arra! what a fool was I?—by my sowl!—I think I'll cry,
When I spake of all this,—it encreases my bliss;
'Twill kill me afore I die.
Fath!—I'll now show my face, t'scape all disgrace,
For me, they'll make a true jst;
No more shall my foes,
Drive me by my nose,
In boggs, o'er my tose;
Spiling brogues and hose,
And carry the empty chast.
Augh! fale now, my back is quite sore, becaze it made me roar,
How it broke all my bones, pulling brick-batts and stones,
To the mill, from Washball's dure.
To hear the pane and smart, I fale in my hart,
My futt is both sick and lame;
With canoe! and bote,
I mudded my cote,
My wife will cut my trote,
The devil take the tote;
Augh! me—they'll make a grate game.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Deel dam 'em aw.

SP.SPEAKER: Rat.
SP.P:
Dis, dis is my own faut, for being too cred'lous, I put too much trust in dem I tought my friends, and dey deceiv'd me. If I had been satisfy'd wid my bus'ness and follow'd a birtuous course of libe, den I should be happy to dis day, and hab nutting to trubble me, but now I hab seen my folly, and former wickedness;
I will take de resolution to lede a new libe, and fol∣low my bus'ness wid honesty and industry, and hab nutting to say to the banities and bexations, of dis wicked world, and from dis time my studdy shall be birtue, to de end of my libe.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Confusion to the vullians!—I maun e'en gang and fut up my shap-bood agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: I can never face my wife after this.

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
SP.P: Nor I, by St Patrick!—Augh, and she'll make no more suppers for poor Trushoop.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: O dea! I'm robb'd of my money, my health, and my ease, nothings left me now but to grieve and lament—how shall I procure my peace again? Let me see! a tnd my bus'ness. What then? if a customer should laugh under the operation of my razor, egad! I should think he laughed at me, for being such a silly o'd dupe, and ten to one, but I might out his throat fr madness—dress a wig eigh? why I should think my blocks grinn'd at me! I'll instantly go and burn them all. If I should hear the noise of children in the street, I should think they bawl'd Canoe! Canoe! confound the word, I would give five hundred pounds, it were high treason to utter it, then I would hang every one of those dogs. Oh dea! what can I do? If I rail against them publicly, I shal only have the cold comfort of "Its a piece of diversion only, nothing else,"—hellish diversion! suppose I should try to laugh it off? alas! alas! I can't do it, I shan't be in a laughing humor, these seven years I'am afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P: Sir, we crave your blessing.— (They kneel down.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Go to the devil! you dog.— (Lifting up his cane, nd stamping on the floor.)
Augh! and deer Lucy, sure and you're not married?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P:
It is so Mr. Trushoop. (Aside.) Pray endea∣vour
to pacify my uncle, pray gentlemen interpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: What does she say? eigh?

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: She says she's married, and begs your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Oh! the gipsey!—I shall run stark-mad! and how dare you do it without my consent? didn't I for∣bid you hussey? eigh!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Pray dear uncle, pardon us!

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: Thief like! break the laws, and then have the assurance to ask for pardon, eigh! no, no you can't plead ignorance, you knew the terms and consequences of disobeying me, now you've done it, and a pretty couple of beggars you are truly! arn't you? (Aside.) But stop! I'm going too fast, hold there, I forgot my own disappointment! the terms are void in them∣selves.—Well—

SP.SPEAKER: Rac.
SP.P: Come, come Mr. Washball, how can you be so angry wid dem, she's a pretty young ting.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: O! lack-a-day! she's old enough to know better.

SP.SPEAKER: Trow.
SP.P: Pardon them Mr. Washball.

SP.SPEAKER: Mean.
SP.P: Pray sir! pardon us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Pray uncle, give us your blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wash.
SP.P: (Aside.) So, so, pardon and blessing too,—what comes next?

SP.SPEAKER: Trus.
